steps.title: Understand how Screen Time works.
steps.content: Understand how Screen Time works. The iOS 12 Screen Time feature allows you to lock down all but a few of your iPhone's apps for a designated period of time, making it impossible to use apps like Facebook and Twitter without using a passcode that you set. This feature is optimal for controlling iPhones belonging to children or shared iPhones in situations where you want to limit a person's app use. If you haven't yet updated your iPhone to iOS 12, you won't be able to use Screen Time. Screen Time can't be used to block all of your iPhone's apps. Some apps, such as Safari, Wallet, and Phone will still be accessible.

steps.title: Open your iPhone's Settings.
steps.content: Open your iPhone's Settings. Tap the Settings app icon, which resembles a grey set of gears on a grey background.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Screen Time.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Screen Time . It's next to a purple-and-white hourglass icon near the top of the Settings page.

steps.title: Tap Downtime.
steps.content: Tap Downtime . This is near the top of the Screen Time page.

steps.title: Tap the white "Downtime" switch .
steps.content: Tap the white "Downtime" switch . The switch will turn green which signifies that Downtime is now enabled.

steps.title: Tap Start.
steps.content: Tap Start . It's in the middle of the page.

steps.title: Select a time at which you want to disable your iPhone.
steps.content: Select a time at which you want to disable your iPhone. Use the hour and minute dials to set the time at which Downtime should begin.

steps.title: Tap End.
steps.content: Tap End . This is below the Start option.

steps.title: Select a time at which you want to re-enable your iPhone.
steps.content: Select a time at which you want to re-enable your iPhone. This should be the time at which you want Downtime to end.

steps.title: Tap the white "Block at Downtime" switch .
steps.content: Tap the white "Block at Downtime" switch . The switch will turn green, signifying that any blocked apps will require your passcode in order to be used during Downtime.

steps.title: Go back to the Screen Time menu.
steps.content: Go back to the Screen Time menu. Tap Screen Time in the top-left corner of the screen to do so.

steps.title: Tap Always Allowed.
steps.content: Tap Always Allowed . It's in the middle of the page. This will open a list of apps that you'll be able to use while Downtime is on.

steps.title: Remove apps if necessary.
steps.content: Remove apps if necessary. If you want to restrict apps that are currently allowed, do the following for each app you want to restrict: Tap red circle to the left of the app. Tap Remove to the right of the app's name. Tap Remove if prompted (only for Messages). It's advisable to leave Messages enabled so that you can send and respond to emergency messages. The Phone app will be enabled by default, and cannot be disabled.

steps.title: Go back to the Screen Time menu.
steps.content: Go back to the Screen Time menu. Tap Screen Time in the top-left corner of the screen to do so.

steps.title: Tap Use Screen Time Passcode.
steps.content: Tap Use Screen Time Passcode . It's near the bottom of the screen. You may have to scroll down to see this option.

steps.title: Set a passcode.
steps.content: Set a passcode. Type in the four-digit passcode you want to use to lock Screen Time, then re-enter the passcode to confirm.

steps.title: Use Screen Time.
steps.content: Use Screen Time. Once Downtime initiates at the Start time you set, most of the iPhone's apps will be unavailable without using the passcode you entered to unlock them. Downtime will automatically turn off at the End time you set.

steps.title: Enable a passcode if necessary.
steps.content: Enable a passcode if necessary. If your iPhone doesn't have a passcode, you'll need to set one by doing the following: [1] X Research source Open your iPhone's Settings . Scroll down and tap Touch ID & Passcode . Tap Turn Passcode On . Enter a passcode twice.

steps.title: Turn off the "Erase Data" feature.
steps.content: Turn off the "Erase Data" feature. The "Erase Data" feature will erase completely your iPhone if a passcode is entered incorrectly 10 times. You can disable this feature by doing the following: [2] X Research source Open your iPhone's Settings . Scroll down and tap Touch ID & Passcode . Scroll all the way down and tap the "Erase Data" switch if it's green. Enter the iPhone's passcode if prompted.

steps.title: Lock your iPhone.
steps.content: Lock your iPhone. Press the Lock button on the side of your iPhone to do so.

steps.title: Press the Home button.
steps.content: Press the Home button. Doing so will wake up the iPhone's screen. If you use Touch ID, make sure you press the Home button with a non-Touch ID finger.

steps.title: Enter repeatedly the wrong passcode.
steps.content: Enter repeatedly the wrong passcode. Doing this seven times in a row will cause your iPhone to become disabled for one minute. Simply typing the same number over and over again won't always trigger the iPhone to disable, so make sure you vary the numbers you're typing.

steps.title: Disable further the iPhone.
steps.content: Disable further the iPhone. While the first batch of incorrect passcode entries will disable the iPhone for only one minute, you can increase the amount of time for which the iPhone is disabled by entering the passcode incorrectly after it becomes enabled again. Entering an incorrect passcode again will disable your iPhone for 5 minutes. Entering an incorrect passcode after the 5-minute lock expires will disable your iPhone for 15 minutes. Entering an incorrect passcode after the 15-minute lock expires will disable your iPhone for 60 minutes. Entering a final incorrect passcode will disable your iPhone until you restore it from iTunes .

steps.title: Understand when to use this method.
steps.content: Understand when to use this method. While Find My iPhone won't disable your iPhone in the same sense as using the passcode will, you can use this feature to lock your iPhone and disable Touch ID if you've misplaced the iPhone. This will only work if your iPhone's Find My iPhone utility is enabled.

steps.title: Open iCloud.
steps.content: Open iCloud. Go to https://www.icloud.com/ in your computer's web browser.

steps.title: Log into your iCloud account.
steps.content: Log into your iCloud account. Enter your Apple ID email address and password in the top text box and bottom text box, respectively, then press â†µ Enter .

steps.title: Click Find iPhone.
steps.content: Click Find iPhone . It's in the middle of the dashboard. Find My iPhone will begin scanning for your iPhone's location. This may take a few minutes.

steps.title: Click All Devices.
steps.content: Click All Devices . This heading is at the top of the page. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click your iPhone's name.
steps.content: Click your iPhone's name. It should be in the drop-down menu. This will open a small window in the upper-right side of the window.

steps.title: Click Lost Mode.
steps.content: Click Lost Mode . This is at the bottom of the window.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . It's in the top-right corner of the window.

steps.title: Click Done.
steps.content: Click Done . This is in the top-right corner of the window. Doing so will lock your iPhone and disable the Touch ID until you unlock it with the passcode. You can type a message into the window before clicking Done if you want to display a message (e.g., "This phone belongs to [your name]") on the iPhone's Lock Screen.
